Depends. If one defines an allele by locus, this usually doesn't happen except in rare cases of polysomy. And then, as usual, the phenotypic effect is the result of the combined chemical effects of the interaction of these sequences with their cellular environments, and the resulting interactions of these cells with the organismal environment in turn. There's no one single rule that determines which particular sequence is phenotypically dominant.

Oh. So I think Hank makes the distinction that p+q=1 only accounts for the frequency of the alleles across the entire population. On the other hand the p^2+2pq+q^2=1 is the frequency of the genotypes across the population which is true because we know that every individual has two alleles.

Its because people have two of each gene, one from the mother and one from the father. Like for example you have two hands that can hold ice cream, you wouldn't just check one hand to see if you had it but both hands at the same time.

Mercedes Cordoway with p+q=1  you're only finding your dominant(W) and recessive (w) allele. But you dont know if youre either WW, Ww or ww.  (P+q)^2= 1^2  helps you find which one you are.

David C Actually, no, the formula is quite useful. First of all, it helps prove that selective pressures (like natural selection) do occur, because otherwise the frequency of alleles in the population would reach the equilibrium predicted by the Hardy-Weinberg formula. Secondly, it helps us estimate the effect those selective pressures have; we do that by comparing the expected/predicted (by the formula) frequencies with the true (observed) frequencies in the population - the difference is owed to the intervening selective pressures.

Biological fitness can essentially just be boiled down to being "the probability of producing offspring". Which means that, in humans, being very attractive might be a sign of fitness, but having a high income might lead to an equal level of fitness - even though it has little to do with genetics.   As a side-note, I was also taught that sometimes sexually selected traits come with deleterious traits packed as extras - which might just explain why many people who are attractive are simultaneously stupid.

"Fitness" is often misunderstood by the layman. In evolutionary terms, fitness means "ability to survive and reproduce in its environment", not necessary muscle definition or a "healthy" appearance. In humans, we are sexually attracted to seemingly healthy individuals, but let's take a look at the birds of paradise - many have ridiculously elongate feathers that actually impede the bird's mobility, but the females find this sexually attractive, despite apparently reducing fitness.  This separates the two forms of selection: Sexual and natural. Sexual selection is based on "who's more attractive" and natural selection on "who isn't dead".  Hope this has helped! :)

So does being sexually attractive mean that one is also able to produce fertile offspring ? I mean is sexual attractiveness equivalent to having a higher than average probability of surviving and reproducing in its environment. I mean why are we attracted to some but not others?

No, sexual attraction does not imply greater fitness. "Why be attracted to less fit individuals?" is actually a very good question. Some have proposed what we call the "handicap principle"; that, for example, being extremely bright colours and broadcasting yourself to predators is a way of "showing off" how able you are to escape predators. If they are advertising themselves to predators and they haven't been eaten yet, then they must be very successful.  Another important point is that violent competition for females (fighting, that is) can cause injury, and so less risky displays of strength (for example a dance) can decide which male (or female) has the right to mate without the need to risk their lives or at the very least, injury.

Hi, it can give you a very rough estimate of what to expect in a population nevertheless. You can also modify it to include fitness etc, which adds a lot of complication :P

It matters because it lets you see how evolution wouldn't have progressed at all and none of these species would have existed, in such a stable population which is forever in equilibrium - and why the factors which disturb this equilibrium are SO important.

It sort of gives you a "control group". You know what the genes of Population X would look like if none of those factors apply. Then when you study the actual genes of Population X and find the results don't match what the equation predicts, you KNOW that some other factor must be affecting them. Having an intuitive feeling that other factors apply isn't the same as having proof. AND, it gives you a starting place for measuring how much those factors affect things.

They both represent alternative forms of a gene. A trait is the phenotypic characteristic that is expressed (brown eyes), and the allele is-at least in simple crosses that doesn't consist of polyploidy-the variation among the gene that is represented in simple crosses as either a capital or lower case letter. Allele pairs are said to be either homozygous recessive, homozygous dominant or heterozygous (dominant) i.e. bb, BB, Bb. 'B' and 'b' are the alleles that constitute a gene, and the phenotypic expression is said to be the trait. Really, I think you're instructor is getting stuck on semantics. Address them in whatever way makes sense to you, but also in a way that makes you do well on exams.

On the Hardy Weinberg equilibrium: It is important to note that the assumptions of the equation (6:00) can act on a sub section of an organism's genome.  For example, take human blood type, where there is no advantage for having one blood type over another and we do not select our sexual partners on that basis.  Accordingly, the allele frequency of blood types is stable over long periods of time.    Props to Dr. Haglund, highschool biology prof at Windward highschool.
